comments.commentBody: Now that we have helped give Iraq a chance at democracy (athough they could ally with Iran and harm us even more) what is the next country where we want to spend $1 Trillion, 4000 American soldier lives and kill 1 Million of its citizens to give it, 8 years from now, a chance at democracy?

felix - I certainly do think players check high today as opposed to when I started watching hockey in the early '60s, but it's not a recent trend. That started happening when the Flyers dominated the game, as Colin Campbell recalls in this post, and it grew as helmets became more common and then mandatory.

There is a lot of controversy surrounding hip checks because some people think they target the knees. There was a move a few years ago to outlaw them, but it didn't pass. Still if a player comes in too low and does target the knees, sometimes you see officials call that. Actually, hip checking is sort of a lost art and I think that's because the puck carriers are traveling at such a high rate of speed, it's hard to time it right; hip checks are all about timing. And I think that's another reason hits got higher, because it's easier for a defender to make contact with the puckcarrier using his upper body.

I think the owners and the GMs are, to some extent, caught between two fears on this question. On one hand, they don't want their players concussed, that's for certain, if only because their players are their biggest assets. On the other hand, I do think there is a real fear in some quarters that the game will get soft if the league moves too far legislating head checks, and they do want to preserver the physical character of the game.

As every one knows, when you get two conflicting schools of thought like that, there's a chance they will negate each other and a standoff will result. So if nothing happens at the end of all this, it may not be because the owners don't respect the players as much as they can't come to a consensus on what action to take.

Thanks for your comment.

Thanks, Dan F - I went back to yesterday's blog and saw that you and others had offered some good advice on speed-solving, and accurate solving in general.  I think part of the reason for my slow-ish pace is that I rarely give a puzzle my complete attention.  My several pets interrupt, the TV is on, my email-notifying puppy trots out, etc.  Plus a couple of years ago I quit doing crosswords and devoted my time to acrostics instead (those archives go way back!)... but reading the Wordplay blog has revived my interest.  I really appreciate the helpful hints!
The Cantina Habarnero....live music and fine food...a must stop for all! The owner, Ed, continues the tradition of hands-on service and friendly atmosphere.

Ouch!  He is an older man, so the bone breaks might have been an effective energy absorption system to protect the rest of his frame.  I wonder if a younger person would have experienced more internal damage.

Cheers Brad, and if you're starting the virtual paddock this season in Bahrain, be sure to ask Nick Duxbury and Matt Beer if they have any more breaking news from the '09 season they'd like to share with their readers ;)

No disrespect Brad, but this item reads a bit like the fake 'revelations' posted on IMDB's WENN news site ('I almost died doing such and such stunt,' 'I almost quit acting!,' etc.). It reads like total PR and is probably not worthy of propagation.

I'm pretty much totally off Hamilton anyway. Yes, Schumi's elbows were too sharp and I believe he genuinely endangered his peers at times; but Hamilton just doesn't seem on the up and up. I was a HUGE fan and supporter of his since I first read about him in Autoweek when he was 13 or something. I thought it would be AWESOME for him to make F1; but instead, his long coronation only served to spoil him almost entirely.

Sir Stirling's 'fault' was that he was probably too loyal to certain teams and manufacturers.  If he'd been a bit more mercenary, he'd have probably won a championship or two by jumping to the 'hot' team.
When I was young and driving fast (?) my passenger would always ask, "Who do you think you are, Stirling Moss?"

Sir Moss celebrated his 80th birthday last September by driving in an hour-long race and posing with comely young ladies at the annual Goodwood Revival in England.
http://www.sportscardigest.com...

My wife and I on our last trip to Quinatana Roo, Yucatan from Denmark...were delighted to have the joy to spend some weeks in Puerto Morelos...Enjoying the live music, Nacho Supremes and great drinks at the Cantina
Habenaro made for a truly enjoyable vacation...The ownere, Ed, was a combination of professional and friendly service...I highly recommmend this fine local establishment.
Unique. Magical. - I'd like to return tomorrow. Jnane Tamsna is a peaceful oasis of beauty and nature just close enough to wonderful, wild and frenetic Marrakech.

I agree that eventually, it's better to get into non-fiction. But keep in mind, there's a traditional argument that even "fiction" is "true."

Fiction especially, is usually about the structure of the human life; characters, in interaction with other people, is really what most fiction is about. So Fiction still has a sort of factual subject: human beings and their behavior. In fact, it is commonly said, it allows us to get a peek even inside the minds of characters; many books narrate the very thoughts of the actors.

So though the plot, the events of fiction, are not quite factual, the plot is often almost incidental and unimportant. What is true about fiction, is its unique - and invaluable - peek into human consciousness.

And since it reflects our own minds to a large extent, it appeals of course, to young people paticularly.

I read a lot of fiction when I was younger; though to be sure, as you get older, you know people well enough; and are more interested in factual matters. For young people, it speaks to where they really live; who they are. And gets them interested in reading, finally.

Eventually, we would hope, they will go on to read nonfiction. Though as children, they read plenty of nonfiction all the time: that's what (hopefully) their school texts are about. Fiction is an escape, really, from what they have to read all the time, for school.

And again, in a way fiction can be (in some cases) not escapist; but can really be the most realistic and helpful - and factual - education of all. As an education into what people are like; and how they think.
We should just have enough presence to assert our legal rights to freedom of the seas.  That means an occasional visit by a small Navy ship.  No big deal.  Not threatening to anybody.

Reading presidential biographies would get students around all the propaganda and nonsense in American history text books. Maybe include some Howard Zinn or James Loewen books. Books about FDR, Teddy Roosevelt, Andrew Jackson, Abe Lincoln, George Washington, and Thomas Jefferson should cover a lot of the important civics issues. Reading biographies of important military figures like Ike, MacArthur, Nimitz, Napoleon, Nelson, Lee & Grant, and Farragut could add some excitement and adventure and sober thinking about historic events. Memoirs of normal people prove there are lots of interesting stories that need to be heard. Seeing history through the people who lived it is much more interesting than a textbook that mentiions sequential events with little context.

Young science students can read about dinosaurs. For older students John McPhee and Steven Jay Gould are great writers who give a big picture of life on earth. Geography can be taught by reading biographies of great explorers. The "Double-Helix" should show students how scientists operate and teach them the basics of DNA. Biology can be taught by reading stories of the voyage of the Beagle.

Books about MLK, Booker T. Washington, Harriet Tubman, George Washington Carver, Frederick Douglass should be a good start for learning black history.

Who was it that said that writing fiction is harder than writing non-fiction because you have to make it believable? There are more strange creatures in the ocean than any science-fiction writer ever thought up. Non-fiction teaches all the great lessons of life that fiction writers attempt. Truth is stranger than fiction.

Heck, reading a good newspaper like the Times can hold students' interest while teaching them something useful.

I think over time we will see companies figuring that the only true safety measure is to have physically separate networks for high-value IP material.
B Texas March 6th, 2010 11:16 am
.........................................
This would not be secure since an intruder would still have access to all files that have been downloaded from the secure system to a system that is connected to the public internet.

A safer method would be to have a separate system to connect to the public internet. A tailored netbook could be used with a Keyboard Mouse Screen switch that would allow the user to easily use this system to go on the internet. An intruder could access this system but since there are no important files on the system nothing could be gained by the hacker except to turn the system into part of a botnet.

The vendor that provides such a tailored netbook that has security by checking for unknown programs would find a very good market. There is a machine out now that only has limited functionality and has no read write storage. The tailored netbook would not need a screen, keyboard, or mouse and it would be easy to include with it a usb flash drive that could be used to check the system for unknown programs. In fact the operating system could be linux. No need for batteries since the machine is for use in an office where there is a power supply. Since this netbook is a limited purpose system the user could periodically format the storage and reload the entire system. These netbooks should probably include a dvd drive which would not add greatly to cost. The vendor could sell the system with a maintenance contract and periodically send out complete updated reloads of the system. This would be a profitable machine for any vendor.

Of course the simplest way to obtain and even modify source code is to bribe the cheap foreign programmers that are paid by American companies and given full access to the source code.

Thank you for bringing this up.  You reminded me of a similar experience I had last week on Facebook, i.e. whether to "like" a disaster-related article.  Might I (excuse-the-expression) "recommend" the NYTImes' "recommend" solution as as a model for Facebook to emulate?

You will never never ever replace what books offer
and you obviously don't even understand what that is.

Good riddance to physicality? You've obviously never
spent hours in an attic thumbing through books that belonged to
a loved one and feeling the soul of the owner and the writer
hovering from the pages, finding notes and flowers tucked between the pages...you also obviously don't like reading in the bathtub, and you obviously don't care about people with eye problems,
and you obviously have a rather confined life. Rattling along a terrible
mountain road in a foreign country for hours, one can find great solace
in a favorite book, sorry you can't access your digital media in such circumstances, and I hope you never will.

I can't believe you once designed books. Obviously the wrong occupation for someone who doesn't really grasp their value in all their "physicality." They used to be works of art, but like everything in the digital culture, now they're just "text." The digital revolution is a sham and it's why everyone under 40 has no soul. I don't get why the NYT is so obsessed with cheerleading everything high tech.

Feh.

You're walking down the street and buy a book and sit down in a park to read it. You get up, stick it in your bag (it's light!) and continue your day walking around this city where you're a tourist. You stop in a cafe and remember the page you marked and go back to re read that great part. You put the book back in your bag and go to the museum. You find a quiet corner after much viewing and rest with your book....You remember another part that confused you and go to reread that. You get on the very crowded tram and have no place to sit, but it's easy to just put the book in front of you and take up where you left off.

You never had to think about thieves, internet access, tired shoulders...not once.

Shall I go on?

As Neil Postman said 'technology imperiously commandeers our most important terminology. It redefines “freedom,” “truth,” “intelligence,” “fact,” “wisdom,” “memory,” “history” – all the words we live by '

Pandora is a fantastic service. It was cool the day I found it, and it's still cool. I find it impressive that the have not lost their core values. Nice job.

Slacker Radio is also very very cool, but very different from Pandora. Pandora was really a rising sun. I appreciate people that take risks on models of business that don't make any sense. They usually don't make sense because they are doing something brand new. Why would models like Pandora make sense?

Thank God there's some dudes out there that still try to do the impossible to give something great to humanity.

Or, maybe that's saying too much. Dunno. Heck, it's great.

In 1985 I browsed the stacks of the old Mid-Manhattan Library and stumbled on the spine of a collection of stories called "The Bottom of the Harbor."  Any current or future technology that might allow me to bump into work as good as Joseph Mitchell's is okay by me.

Pandora is truly amazing. At first it was a bit repetitive but the more you use it, the better it gets. For a truly personal experience, try accruing more than 50 preset stations and turn on quickmix. So much more convenient than wasting time building a playlist in traditional media players (though the zune software is pretty promising).

Reading on an e-reader, such as the Kindle, is actually far easier and more convenient than reading from a printed book.  When the Courier comes out sometime next year, e-writing will also become much easier and more efficient. So both literary aspects, reading and writing, have been greatly improved by technology. Since the Courier also serves as an e-reader, as well as being an e-writer, a single device could be utilized for both reading and writing...a physical book can't do this. This changes everything.
